video.title: Full Ethical Hacking Course - Network Penetration Testing for Beginners (2019)
video.description:
Learn network penetration testing / ethical hacking in this full tutorial course for beginners. This course teaches everything you need to know to get started with ethical hacking and penetration testing. You will learn the practical skills necessary to work in the field. Throughout the course, we will develop our own Active Directory lab in Windows, make it vulnerable, hack it, and patch it. We'll cover the red and blue sides. We'll also cover some of the boring stuff like report writing :).

This course was originally live streamed weekly on Twitch and built from lessons learned in the previous week. 

💻 GitHub repo (for homework): https://github.com/hmaverickadams/Beginner-Network-Pentesting

🎥 Course created by The Cyber Mentor. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0ArlFuFYMpEewyRBzdLHiw
🐦 The Cyber Mentor on Twitter: https://twitter.com/thecybermentor

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00) - Course Introduction/whoami
⌨️ (6:12) -  Part 1: Introduction, Notekeeping, and Introductory Linux
⌨️ (1:43:45) - Part 2: Python 101
⌨️ (3:10:05) - Part 3: Python 102 (Building a Terrible Port Scanner)
⌨️ (4:23:14) - Part 4: Passive OSINT
⌨️ (5:41:41) - Part 5: Scanning Tools & Tactics
⌨️ (6:56:42) - Part 6: Enumeration
⌨️ (8:31:22) - Part 7: Exploitation, Shells, and Some Credential Stuffing
⌨️ (9:57:15) - Part 8: Building an AD Lab, LLMNR Poisoning, and NTLMv2 Cracking with Hashcat
⌨️ (11:13:20) - Part 9: NTLM Relay, Token Impersonation, Pass the Hash, PsExec, and more
⌨️ (12:40:46) - Part 10: MS17-010, GPP/cPasswords, and Kerberoasting
⌨️ (13:32:33) - Part 11: File Transfers, Pivoting, Report Writing, and Career Advice

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Edward Pan
topLevelComment.text:
big thank you to TCM, I really appreciated all your hard work in helping us learn!
.
going to leave a little note for future me to read:
I started off summer 2022 going broke. Literally hitting 0 in my bank account. Just a 23 year old hitting quarter life crisis. Gave music an honest shot. I moved to LA (next to USC) trying to get work and getting into the industry for around 8 months or so. Worked in the audio engineering field and majored in violin performance in CSULB's conservatory. I'd get calls to be a "runner" or perform little violin gigs here and there. All the while working in our family's little restaurant in the nice city of Arcadia. Work's not easy. My mom literally damaged her ulnar nerve and her hand can't function properly anymore. I've lost count of how many holidays we've missed, and how many times we had to stay over night and take turns working 20 hour shifts over weeks. Even then, we didn't make much. With rent, utilities, and taxes adding up for a small business we pretty much just evened out the 5 years that we were at May's Cafe.

At first I was convinced to do web development by a friend who also transitioned from music. He's probably pretty far along that track now. Big shoutout to Matt! Learned some javaScript in July and spent a steady 8 hours a day studying. School wasn't in session so I had the luxury of time on my hands. Family business is so run down anyways, I had so much downtime to follow tutorials on CSX and YouTube. The honest truth came to me and I found that many devs nowadays are struggling too. Sure there's a lot of YouTube success stories, but just looking at Indeed's job search. There'd be over 100-200 applicants for web dev job openings that are posted within the hour. Many of them requiring really high standards in degrees and certifications, and who knows how many of those hoards of applicants even made it into the interview.

Coming from a music background, everything tech seemed to intimidating to me. I reluctantly chose cyber security after my friend told me about the OSCP cert. He said he'd help me get connections if I get good enough, but pass the OSCP first. A certification that can drastically increase your chances of getting a job? I chased after it. And yes I know, I seemed so shallow just chasing it for monetary reasons. To be fair, I still had like only $2 in my bank account. I was desperate, and no, a minimum wage job would not support the minimum $3k that I had contracted myself to that I had to pay monthly for the family restaurant. COVID loans have all been depleted as well.

I didn't like cyber security at first. Professor Messer's security+ videos was just full of terms that I didn't understand, and it was just so dry. Then I stumbled onto this video, and I was surprised that I was able to follow along. Sure I had to rewatch some stuff, or Google things whenever network things came up. Getting stuck on Python with no one around to help and having to redo the exercise 10 or 20 times just for everything to burn into my memory was fun. Have I mentioned that school started again for me? Yeah getting a music degree at this point is probably very pointless, but I have no regrets for all the fun people and experiences that I've made. It does take up so much time though. I'm typing this literally coming after a 5 production session; into a 3 hour delivery for the Cafe; going to Barnes & Noble to study (this course); coming back to the restaurant to eat while finishing this course. I just finished the video. Seeing the "fin" at the end almost made me cry. That last lab was hard for me (I'll probably do it a couple more times), and I can hopefully celebrate it with a sandwich or something someday.

Cyber security for sure grew on me. An old high school friend (who works professionally on the blue team) recommended Darknet Diaries to me, and I now realized the scale and enormity of cyber warfare. It's fun, though a lot of these exploits have already been patched in a short 3 years, I enjoy the new challenges I face daily, whether it be on HTB or TryHackMe. Hopefully I'd get good enough by the time I finish my music degree and can get my first attempt at OSCP soon after. But for now, 14 hour work/school days is really taking a toll on me. It's a world that I can't wait to begin exploring though.

Anyways, whenever I feel down or sad or something I'd probably come back to this video. Since I spent so much time redoing all the exercises around the practice rooms and gym at school. Around libraries and local Barnes & Nobles that I'd pass by. Or even at home. TCM's guides are literally my foundation to what I'll do moving forward. I'm so blessed to have the support of my friends and family. Hoping that seeing this message in the future would motivate myself even just a little.

Good luck Ed, you got this!

topLevelComment.author: David Glass
topLevelComment.text:
When we scanned for ip addresses I liked multithreading because it is faster and I have multiple cores but I don't like seeing ips out of order. This mini python script can be piped into to fix that :)
import sys

ips = sys.stdin.read().split('\n') # makes a list of lines from stdin
lol = [[int(section) for section in ip.split('.')] for ip in ips if len(ip.split('.')) == 4] # makes a list of lists (lol) where each list has four int elements representing the ipv4  
for ipLst in sorted(lol): # handles iteration over the new sorted list of lists
    print('.'.join([str(num) for num in ipLst])) # for each list the numbers are cast to string and concatenated with the '.' char before write to stdout

! IMPORTANT IF YOU WATCH THIS IN 2022 !

1. You need to login with username and password BOTH "kali" (without the quotes)
2. Go to Terminal and type: sudo passwd root
Now you can set a new password for root and if you switch the user to root you will have all permissions and rights (like admin) !

it was the only way for me

replies.author: absolutegodking
replies.text: So, if you are looking for a folder called “Root”, it isn’t going to happen on a default Linux install. If, however, you are trying to access restricted data in the “/“ folder, you will need to be logged in as the root user, or a user in the sudoers group. As a non-root user with access to sudo, you can drop to a root shell in many ways, such as “sudo -i”.

topLevelComment.author: Christopher Lowery
topLevelComment.text:
Looking like a good course so far!  Two things that would really help out, though:

- Add chapter/part markers so we can see where each part is on the timeline bar
- Trim more of the parts that aren't relevant, especially in the beginning of each part when you go into things like giveaways that were only relevant to those taking the class at the time.  It's a minor thing, but it really isn't useful to keep

Alternatively, break the parts into their own videos together as a series, which will make keeping track of where you are a lot simpler

topLevelComment.author: Jamison Martino
topLevelComment.text: Posting my weekly notes in the replies of this comment :)

replies.author: Jamison Martino
replies.text:
Week 2

Writing Basic Scripts - Python 101

https://darknetdiaries.com/imgs/Python-CheatSheet.pdf

Python Basics:     

If you write a python script in a normal text editor (not an ide) your program should start with “#!/bin/ python3” to point at the fact that we are using python.     
print - print(string) - prints to the terminal (string has to be with “” or ‘’)

Math Operators: 

 + - add     
- subtract  
* - multiply 
/ - divide 
** - exponent - power of     
% - modulo - the remainder of a division 
// - number without leftovers - cleans a number - float -> int     
+= - add a number into the already existing value in the variable 
-= - subtract a number from an the already existing value in the variable

String Methods:     

len - len([var name]) checks the length of a variable        
upper - [var].upper() - Capitalizes the letters in the variable      
lower - [var].lower() - returns the letters to normal (reverse capitalization)
title - [var].title() - Capitalizes the first letter of every word in a variable 
STRING ≠ INT !!!

Declaring Variables:     

data means also variables!      
[name] = [data] - This type of declaration will automatically set the type of the variable     
[name] int([data]) - This type of declaration will set the var type to int      
[name] float([data]) - This type of declaration will set the var type to float. 
[name] str([data]) - type of declaration will set the var type to String.      
To convert a variable to a different type you can just use [type]([data])
output: 29 // the print command can only print strings      
type(data) - return the type of variable the data / variable entered is     
Int variables does not round up or down they just use the first whole number available for example - 29.8 -> 29.     

Functions:

def [name of the function] ([function input variable]): - defining a function      
return [var or operation or some kind of value resulting code] - return gives the information back to the program after the function has ended.     
when defining a function input (A parameter) you use the name of the variable inside the function to access that value. 
You can add multiple parameters into a function.     

Boolean Expressions:      

True expressions:         
bool1 = True     
bool2 = 3*3 == 9     

 False expressions:         

bool3 = False
bool4 = 3*3 != 9

Relational and Logical operators:      

Relational:         
> - greater then         
< - less then         
>= - greater then equal to         
<= - less then equal to
== - equal to 

Logical: 

and - both statements have to be true         
or - one of operators have to be true (or both true)         
not - Inverts the boolean value     

Conditional Statements: 

 if [Condition]: - check if the Condition is true and if yes executes the code below     
 else - executes the code below if the statement of the if is not true     
 elif - can come between an if and an else statement as another condition to check if the if is not true      

There are no switch statements in python! 

Lists:     

[name of the list] = [[value1], [value 2] , [value 3[ ....]     
[name of the list].append([data]) - will add the data to the end of the list      
[name of the list].pop() - will remove the last piece of data in the list (or a certain place in the list if given data inside the () of what place to remove)     
zip([list 1] , [list 2]) - will combine the two lists and save the values in the same place , data 0 of list 1 will be stored with data 0 of list 2 in the following way :      ([data 0] , [data 0]).          
 lists count from 0 - so to print the second value we use [name][1]     
 we can call multiple values by calling out +1 more value then we want. for example to print value 1   and 2 we will use [name][0:2] this will print 0 and 1.     
we can print the entire list from a certain point up to (or down to) the entire list by not giving a value. [0: ] or [ :3] this will print all of the list or everything up to the 4th item.     
negative items (-1) will pull the last item in the list     

Tuples:
     
A tuple is like a list but cannot be modified. 
To make a tuple you need to use () instead of [] in a list      

For loops:

for [variable] in [Something with value (can be a list, variable...): - This loop will add 1 to the first variable until it reaches the end of the second variable (print all the list, all the numbers in an int...)     

While loop:

while [statement]: - this loop will execute as long as the statement is true

While python is important to understand, it isn’t required knowledge. A penetration tester can technically know nothing about python and still do a good job. However it is extremely helpful to be able to understand different scripts and even be able to write your own. Knowing a programming language is completely needed for almost every other cybersec field. TL;DR, by the end of the course you should able to write basic scripts, and understand how intermediate to difficult scripts work.
===

topLevelComment.author: Schuyler Reinken
topLevelComment.text:
For anyone who might be watching this now:
I found that commands like `service apache2 start` no longer exist in kali.

Instead use
`systemctl start apache2`

Also:
ifconfig and iwconfig are outdated and not installed by default.
instead you can use commands like:
`ip address`
`ip route`

topLevelComment.author: johnny zheng
topLevelComment.text:
For anyone doing this now with the 2020.x version: the Username and password is 'kali'

The only issue is that you want the root account (the super admin account) for this course instead of kali, so follow these steps:

1: Issue command “sudo su” in terminal
2: Enter the password for the kali account
3: Issue command "passwd root" in terminal
4: Make a password for the root account and retype it
5: Click logout and type 
username: "root" (no caps) and
password: "{the one that you entered at step 4}"


by lua

topLevelComment.author: Slava Ukraini!
topLevelComment.text:
Nice video, 
Around 5:55:30, when you do a ping scan of your network, nmap wrongly reports hosts that are up, when they're really not. This is due to the network configuration of the kali linux VM being set to NAT. I recommend using Bridged instead, your VM will get its own ip address, and will appear as just another PC on your network. In any case, it avoids the issues of using a NAT interface.

topLevelComment.author: MrYan
topLevelComment.text:
A summery of the first lesson: 
Lesson 1:

- Taking notes
	*take notes with alot of child pathes 
	*always screenshot 
	*Be orgenized

- Linux
   Navigation Commands:
	*passwd - change password
	*ls = list directory (Can point at any point on the machine)      (-la a flag that lists all + premissions and hidden files)
	*pwd - print working directory - check where I am at
	*cd - change directory (Can adress at any point on the machine)
	*mkdir - make directroy
	*rmdir - remove a directory
	*rm - remove files
	*echo sends data (if not destenation is given the echo will print the data to the terminal)
	*cp - copy a file (source] [destanation])
	*mv - move a file ([source] [destanation])
	*locate - locate a file (locate [filename] )
	*updatedb - updates the directory database (must run this before running locate)
	*man - manual page of any command	
	*grep - search for the following words ( can be used to check if a file contains specific info)
	
	**Linux is case sensetive so be aware of your capital letters!
	** ./ - your directory right now
	** ../- previous folder
	** ~ - the root of the system
	** | - pipe the output of one command into the next command after the |
	** > - use the command on the following file (Overwrite previous information that was in the file)
	** >> - use the command on the following file (Add the information to the previous information that was in the file)

   Privleges and User Commands:
	*cat - reads a file to the terminal	
	*chmod - change premissions for a file (perms go from lvl 0 - 7 and are typed with 3 number for (user group everyone) for a detailed      explanation on Linux permissions visit the node “Linux perms” (+x execute perms))
	*adduser - make a new user 
	*sudo - give root presmissions to the next command (sudo ..... [the command])
	*su - switch user
	
   Network Commands:
   	*ifconfig - print network information
   	*iwconfig - wireless networkj information
   	*ping - ping an ip adress (-c flag lets you say how much times you want to ping a machine)
    *arp -a - send out an arp request to check for machines on the network
    *netstat -a -  shows all open ports and what is connected to those ports
    *route - shows a routing table
   
   Viewing Creating and Editing Commands:
   	*history - lists the 15 commands you entered ( (history | grep [command]) this command shows you all the times you run a command on the machine (including syntex))
   	*touch - create a file
   	*nano - use the nano text editor
   	*apt-get install [program name] - install a program on the machine (can be run without the install)
   	*apt install - install a file from the system / kali - server
   	*apt purge *program name* - (You have to use the * *) removes everything that has to do with a certain program
   	*pip install - run an installer for local files
   	*git clone - clone a github repository (This is a plugin and does not come preinstalled on most linux distros!)

   Webserver Commands:
   	*service apache2 start - start a webserver
   	*service ssh start - start an ssh server
   	*service postgresql start - a service that starts with metasploit
   	*service apache2 stop - stops the webserver
   	*systemctl enable [program name] - start the service when the machine turns on
   
   Importent files/Directorys in Linux:
   	*/etc/passwd - a file that stores all the users in the system
    */etc/shadow - stores all of the passwords in the system
	*/var/log/auth.log - authntication reports

replies.author: JamesE
replies.text:
I work in one of those school as ICT administrator and good luck with cabled projectors. Most modern schools these days have left projectors and moved to a smart tv which could be hacked but you aint hacking no HDMI wired projector lol. You could turn it off or hack the attached pc but with restricted rights you may have issues. Not only that pupil accounts are highly restricted and cant even see the C drive these days but if there is one thing I have learned and that is the only system you cannot hack is the one you cannot access ie offline so have fun and good luck.

Oh one thing dont get caught as what we did to the last hacker we caught you wouldnt want to happen to you! It would greatly affect your education as it did theirs and like I said to him - no one to blame but yourself.

Depending on your wordlist, it could take you from 1 minute to 100 years to crack the password or even more.... Goodluck :)

topLevelComment.author: Abhishek Negi 3313
topLevelComment.text:
Let me warn you before you waste your 8 hours of your efforts.....

See I am not gonna be toxic and I clearly don't dislike this video or channels free education thought.. YouTube is great source of education today BUT when it comes to CAREER things are a bit complex.....
 Whatever I have to say is for those with the attitude of I WILL LEARN FREE FROM YOUTUBE AND WILL BE HIRED IN NO TIME!😎😎 because I WAS ONE OF THEM TOO🙁🙁(so this is more of a confessional advice)

See what I want you to understand is... What you are going to get in your CV after taking this 8 hour course is...your Notes only...
So suppose you took the complete course and you are like me...you will go for the job straight! Right!? Well that's all wrong....
You may go to freelance website maybe different companies and the first thing you come to know about is...there is CUT THROAT competition people are dying to working for free just to get some experience...of course other people who were same like me (youtube/udemy students) 
So you figure out you need a strong CV and for that you need good intership experience , so now you go to internshala (or other similar websites) to get an intership.... again the competition problem shows up here ... People are so competitive they have done 3 different courses 5 different courses, and of course they will be selected..why would a company manage 5 interns when its getting 5 employees in one!
THAT WAS ME! and I think nearly all of people who start with this FREE! learning attitude endup like this(or learning cheap from udemy- both are quite the same thing) ..comes out the FREE was the most expensive option 😵😵 

What was the solution for me then (or for people like me)....
SIMPLE...1) drop the FREE attitude ...just for saving 6000-7000 you are talking yourself into unecessary trouble!
2) *MOST IMPORTANT* CHOOSE an education platform which provides you personal MENTOR attention like college and an intership...so basically find an online college (and yes it is rare as it sounds like)

After I realized this it took me some time to find out one such platform. Then I really discovered how helpful a mentor's guidance can be and got a really good intership as they promised and easily got freelance contracts ....much easier then it was before 
So goodluck on your search , that's what I wanted to convey you and if you have read this far ..... please don't do the mistake i did...

replies.author: Upcycle Electronics
replies.text:
I'm no expert, but if you can handle the frustrations of learning Arch from the Arch wiki you're off to a good start. It's easy to cheat and find 3rd party Arch tutorials, but the native wiki has far more info. The down side is the gigantic difference between a guide and a tutorial. There are no tutorials on the Arch wiki. 
  Try really securing an Arch install with a DAC and MAC, managing PAM and groups, setup IPTables for your firewall, then figure out AppArmor, FireJail, Audit, and Docker....at least this is what I've been playing with.

topLevelComment.author: Emmet Edwards
topLevelComment.text:
Anyone watching this now and wondering why things aren't working correctly...


The Kali developers thought it would be a good idea to completely screw up the entire reason for running Kali (all root all the time by default) and move towards the current standard model of an unprivileged user that has to sudo everything.


This breaks a large chunk of the information in this video. If you're following along and something doesn't work, sudo into it and that MIGHT work. 



At that point it makes you wonder why you're using Kali when you can just run a standard, much more feature-complete, Linux distro and install whatever packages you need.

topLevelComment.author: Ian -
topLevelComment.text: After I finish the course and understand it, can I call myself a cybersecurity expert, or specifically, a hacker? If not, where do I continue?

replies.author: RodCornholio
replies.text:
Expert, no.  Ethical hacker...depends on your actions.  Remember, being ethical doesn't mean the actions you take are legal.  

As far as where to continue, well, that is as far as you wish within whatever limitations restricts you, voluntary or otherwise.  I would recommend pursuing something specific that you are motivated to explore, especially if you can connect that with a specific goal.  Example:  you're interested in Python (general) so you decide to do "X" with Python.  Have you mastered Python?  No.  Did you learn something along the way and have fun?  Hopefully.  You've probably deepened your skill/knowledge of something SPECIFIC.  This also works in reverse.  Example:  I want to do "X".  Now you learn what's needed to do "X".  If successful, you may have BROADENED your knowledge/skills, but not deepened anything specific.

It's a broad, multidisciplinary field.  Creativity and exploration are at the core of the original meaning (in my opinion) of what it means to be a hacker.  It's a sacred, personal journey but there are folks to help you along the way...or to collaborate with.

Best Regards

topLevelComment.author: Giuliano Bellini
topLevelComment.text: The reason why gedit and other GTk tools (Gedit, Gimp, leafpad, etc) are not working is because you're logged on X display with one user but running the command with another one, thus the "cannot open display" message , note when you were showing the su and sudo commands, you actually su to "-" and not back to root, you'd need to run these commands with same user privilege that your current X display is running (root)

topLevelComment.author: Adel Ambeleson
topLevelComment.text: Surely, to know if a pinged machine is up it is denoted by the packets received not the one line stating the packet size. Granted you can do it your way, but if the received packets is 0 then the host didn't get the packet, meaning it is not online (that along with the packet loss ratio, this would be able to show if a host WAS up and went down during the ping as well, your way would not demonstrate such things leaving you under the impression that a previously up host is still up when it went down mid-ping). Your way seems far too ambiguous a method. I am in no way saying anything of what you say is incorrect, it indeed is correct. But it is best to know the way a man page would describe it in case further reading on the subject is mandated further down the line (also, it is the way we get taught it in uni - at least in the UK)

topLevelComment.author: Adel Ambeleson
topLevelComment.text: systemctl has replaced services. systemctl start apache2 (to start it as you did with services apache2 start) and swap start for enable to leave it as a default service that starts on boot. services command is outdated and according to my sources soon to be obsolete. Great video though and I will continue it to the end,... Thanks

cd                 cd-fix-profile     cd-it8

topLevelComment.author: DesertStoneStudio
topLevelComment.text: Sooo...can I run Kali on a USB and still follow the course without issues?

replies.author: DesertStoneStudio
replies.text: @Septim your welcome! Good luck :D

replies.author: Septim
replies.text: DesertStoneStudio I'll definitely give it a try, thanks for the info :)

replies.author: DesertStoneStudio
replies.text: @Septim no. I haven't run into any issues so far. The first time I tried it I used a metal flash drive. That didn't go so well. Got super hot and I think some files got corrupted but I haven't had any issues with the new plastic one. Been running kali off it for about a month now, just learning a little here and there. I've got a sudo user account, changed wall papers, and updated and everything is still there and running fine.

replies.author: Septim
replies.text: DesertStoneStudio Wow that's actually a smart move! If i may ask did you encounter any issues with this method? I'm currently using a vm but the idea of having a portable and persistent kali is really tempting.

replies.author: DesertStoneStudio
replies.text:
@Septim actually I've made it a persistent usb. I've updated and installed new packages and as long as I keep using kali persistent  (as opposed to live) my updates remain. I'm using a plastic 64gb usb so I don't overheat it.

Of course I have to restart and boot to usb from my laptop every time I want to go into Linux but I like the portability and I can switch from one laptop to another or a desktop if one or the other is rendering or busy with another project.

Burpsuite, Msfconsole, ruby, python libs and etc. Few days ago i was trying to get headers and data json items from school website API with grades, messages and etc which i need to python requests in my project. I use Windows daily and i tried to install programs like Burpsuite on it and had problems with CA Certificates on every website. So Kali Linux is not only for hackers. It's good for overall IT work.
